riskScore.title: Risk Score
riskScore.description: A calibrated probability (0-1) estimating the likelihood that a contract involves corruption patterns. Based on 16 statistical features compared against documented corruption cases. Higher = more suspicious.

riskLevel.title: Risk Level
riskLevel.description: Categorization based on risk score: Critical (>=50%), High (>=30%), Medium (>=10%), Low (<10%). These thresholds are aligned with OECD procurement benchmarks.

singleBid.title: Single Bid
singleBid.description: A competitive procedure (not direct award) where only one vendor submitted a bid. This is a red flag because competitive processes should attract multiple bidders. If only one shows up, it may indicate bid-rigging or market manipulation.

directAward.title: Direct Award
directAward.description: A contract awarded directly to a vendor without competitive bidding. Legal in Mexico under certain conditions (emergencies, sole source). Having one bid in a direct award is expected — it's NOT the same as a single bid.

vendorConcentration.title: Vendor Concentration
vendorConcentration.description: How much of a sector's total procurement value goes to a single vendor. High concentration means one vendor dominates — a top predictor of corruption risk in our model (+0.43 coefficient).

mahalanobisDistance.title: Mahalanobis Distance
mahalanobisDistance.description: A statistical measure of how unusual a contract is across ALL 16 risk dimensions simultaneously. Like asking: 'How far is this contract from normal?' Higher values = more anomalous.

zScore.title: Z-Score
zScore.description: A standardized measure showing how many standard deviations a value is from the sector/year average. A z-score of +2 means the value is unusually high compared to similar contracts.

hhi.title: HHI (Herfindahl-Hirschman Index)
hhi.description: A market concentration measure (0-10,000). Below 1,500 = competitive market. 1,500-2,500 = moderately concentrated. Above 2,500 = highly concentrated. Used to detect vendor monopolies.

puLearning.title: PU Learning
puLearning.description: Positive-Unlabeled learning: a technique for training models when we only know some corrupt contracts (positive) but the rest are unknown (unlabeled, not necessarily clean). Our model uses the Elkan & Noto (2008) correction.

aucRoc.title: AUC-ROC
aucRoc.description: Area Under the Receiver Operating Curve — measures how well the model distinguishes corrupt from clean contracts. 0.5 = random guessing, 1.0 = perfect. Our v5.0 model achieves 0.960 (test AUC).

industryMismatch.title: Industry Mismatch
industryMismatch.description: When a vendor wins contracts in a sector that doesn't match their primary business. For example, a construction company winning health procurement contracts. Suggests shell company or favoritism.

priceAnomaly.title: Price Anomaly
priceAnomaly.description: Contract amount that is statistically unusual compared to similar contracts in the same sector and year. Detected using Tukey's IQR method — values beyond 1.5x the interquartile range are flagged.

cobidding.title: Co-Bidding Pattern
cobidding.description: When two or more vendors consistently appear together in bidding procedures. Can indicate legitimate specialization, but high co-bid rates with alternating wins suggest bid rotation (a form of collusion).

yearEnd.title: Year-End Timing
yearEnd.description: Contracts awarded in December, when agencies rush to spend remaining budget. This 'December dump' creates pressure to award quickly, reducing oversight and increasing corruption risk.

thresholdSplitting.title: Threshold Splitting
thresholdSplitting.description: Multiple contracts awarded to the same vendor on the same day, potentially to keep each contract below a threshold that would require competitive bidding. A classic procurement fraud technique.

networkRisk.title: Network Risk
networkRisk.description: Risk from vendor relationships — companies that share addresses, legal representatives, or consistently bid together. Network membership can indicate shell company networks or bid-rigging cartels.

confidenceInterval.title: Confidence Interval
confidenceInterval.description: The range within which the true risk score likely falls (95% confidence). A score of 0.35 [0.22, 0.48] means we estimate 35% corruption probability, but it could reasonably be between 22% and 48%.

calibratedProbability.title: Calibrated Probability
calibratedProbability.description: A risk score that represents an actual estimated probability of corruption, not an arbitrary number. Our v5.0 model produces calibrated probabilities validated against documented corruption cases.

perSectorModel.title: Per-Sector Model
perSectorModel.description: Separate statistical models trained for each of the 12 sectors. Corruption patterns differ: Health → vendor concentration, Energy → industry mismatch, Infrastructure → network relationships.

groundTruth.title: Ground Truth
groundTruth.description: Documented, verified corruption cases used to train and validate the model. We use 15 cases with 27 vendors and 26,582 contracts across all 12 sectors, including IMSS, Segalmex, Odebrecht, and more.

adPeriod.title: Ad Period
adPeriod.description: Days between publication of a procurement opportunity and the contract award. Very short periods (<15 days) may indicate the process was rushed to favor a predetermined vendor.

rfc.title: RFC (Tax ID)
rfc.description: Registro Federal de Contribuyentes — Mexico's tax identification number for businesses and individuals. Used to uniquely identify vendors. Coverage varies: 0.1% in 2002-2010 data to 47% in 2023-2025.

compranet.title: COMPRANET
compranet.description: Mexico's federal electronic procurement platform, operational since 1996 and mandatory for all purchases above threshold. Abolished by Congress on April 10, 2025, replaced by ComprasMX. Before the formal replacement, 1.9 million contracts from 2012–2023 were already removed from public access in August 2024. Source of all 3.1M contracts in this database.

licitacionPublica.title: Licitación Pública (Open Tender)
licitacionPublica.description: The most transparent procurement procedure under Mexican law. Required for contracts above legal value thresholds. Involves a public notice period (minimum 20 days), unlimited bidders, and mandatory publication on COMPRANET. In practice, only 29% of federal contracts use this procedure — the other 71% skip open competition.

laassp.title: LAASSP
laassp.description: Ley de Adquisiciones, Arrendamientos y Servicios del Sector Público — Mexico's federal procurement law, first enacted January 4, 2000. Defines when government agencies must use open competitive bidding vs. direct award, sets value thresholds, and establishes publication requirements. The original law was abrogated and replaced by a new version in April 2025.

inai.title: INAI
inai.description: Instituto Nacional de Transparencia, Acceso a la Información y Protección de Datos Personales — Mexico's independent transparency watchdog, established 2002. Citizens and journalists could appeal to INAI when government agencies denied information requests. Constitutionally abolished December 20, 2024. Replaced by 'Transparencia para el Pueblo,' an agency under the executive branch, operating on approximately 2% of INAI's former budget.

comprasmx.title: ComprasMX
comprasmx.description: CompraNet's replacement platform, launched April 18, 2025. Built on the same technical architecture as 'Tianguis Digital,' Mexico City's procurement platform during Sheinbaum's tenure as head of government — which disclosed no contracts during that period. The new platform operates under a 5-year data retention rule that could eventually remove historical contract records from public access.

sector.title: Sector
sector.description: One of 12 federal government spending categories (Health, Education, Energy, etc.) classified from Mexico's 'Ramo' budget codes. Each sector has different procurement patterns and risk profiles.

sfp.title: SFP (Ministry of Public Administration)
sfp.description: Secretaría de la Función Pública — Mexico's government accountability ministry. Maintains the official registry of companies sanctioned from federal contracting (Proveedores y Contratistas Sancionados). Companies on this list are prohibited from winning government contracts for the sanction period.

rupc.title: RUPC (Unified Vendor Registry)
rupc.description: Registro Único de Proveedores y Contratistas — Mexico's unified registry of companies eligible for federal contracting. Companies receive compliance grades based on performance history. Was hosted on CompraNet (abolished April 2025); continuity under ComprasMX uncertain.

vendor_concentration.label: Vendor Concentration
vendor_concentration.mexico_note: RUBLI's strongest predictor. Reflects concentration-based corruption patterns in IMSS Ghost Companies, Segalmex, and COVID-19 cases — the three largest training cases.

price_volatility.label: Price Volatility
price_volatility.key_citation: Porter & Zona (1993): Price manipulation detectable in bid distributions
price_volatility.mexico_note: New in v5.0. Vendors with wildly varying contract amounts relative to sector norms. The strongest predictor in the v5.0 global model.

institution_diversity.label: Institution Diversity
institution_diversity.key_citation: Coviello & Mariniello (2014): Competition and transparency reduce award concentration
institution_diversity.mexico_note: Vendors serving many different institutions are less suspicious — they have legitimate broad reach. Negative coefficient.

win_rate.label: Win Rate
win_rate.validation_strength: Strong — abnormal win rates suggest market capture
win_rate.key_citation: Conley & Decarolis (2016): Bid rings detectable via win pattern analysis
win_rate.mexico_note: New in v5.0. A vendor winning contracts at a rate far above the sector baseline signals preferential access.

single_bid.label: Single Bid
single_bid.key_citation: Charron et al. (2017), Journal of Politics
single_bid.mexico_note: Low coefficient because competitive procedures with 1 bidder are rare in Mexico — direct award is used instead when competition is restricted. Z-score normalization accounts for sector baseline.

direct_award.label: Direct Award
direct_award.key_citation: OECD (2016): Preventing Corruption in Public Procurement
direct_award.mexico_note: Mexico issues ~70% of contracts as direct awards. The z-score normalizes this baseline. Positive coefficient in v5.0 (was negative in v4.0 before diversifying ground truth).

industry_mismatch.label: Industry Mismatch
industry_mismatch.key_citation: Fazekas & Kocsis (2020), British Journal of Political Science
industry_mismatch.mexico_note: Vendor's primary industry doesn't match the contract sector. A food distributor winning IT contracts, or a cleaning company winning construction contracts.

same_day_count.label: Same-Day Award Count
same_day_count.mexico_note: Multiple contracts awarded to the same vendor on the same day, suggesting artificial splitting to stay below competitive bidding thresholds.

network_member_count.label: Network Membership
network_member_count.key_citation: Fazekas, Skuhrovec & Wachs (2020): Network analysis of procurement graphs
network_member_count.mexico_note: Vendor belongs to a group of related entities sharing officers, addresses, or bidding patterns. In v4.0 this was negative (artifact); v5.0 corrected to +0.064.

year_end.label: Year-End Award
year_end.mexico_note: Contract awarded in December, consistent with budget-flushing behavior. Weak predictor in RUBLI — direct awards are common year-round.

institution_risk.label: Institution Risk Type
institution_risk.mexico_note: Some institution types (municipalities, state agencies) have historically higher irregularity rates than federal agencies.

ad_period_days.label: Advertisement Period
ad_period_days.validation_strength: Negative — longer periods = more risk in Mexico
ad_period_days.mexico_note: Negative sign is counterintuitive: known-bad vendors tend to operate through normal-length procedures rather than rushed ones. Z-score captures deviation from sector baseline.

sector_spread.label: Sector Spread
sector_spread.mexico_note: New in v5.0. Vendors operating across many sectors are less suspicious — diversified business reduces corruption probability.

price_ratio.label: Price Ratio
price_ratio.key_citation: World Bank INT (2019): Warning Signs of Fraud
price_ratio.mexico_note: Contract amount vs. sector median. Near-zero coefficient because price_volatility (new v5.0 feature) absorbs much of the price signal.

co_bid_rate.label: Co-Bid Rate
co_bid_rate.validation_strength: No signal in current training data
co_bid_rate.key_citation: Porter & Zona (1993): Co-bidding as collusion indicator
co_bid_rate.mexico_note: Regularized to zero. Co-bidding patterns don't discriminate in Mexico's training data because dominant cases involve concentration, not coordinated bidding rings. Collusion Detection tab provides separate heuristic analysis.

price_hyp_confidence.label: Price Hypothesis Confidence
price_hyp_confidence.key_citation: Tukey IQR method for outlier detection
price_hyp_confidence.mexico_note: IQR-based statistical outlier confidence score. Near-zero coefficient — price_volatility and price_ratio absorb the price signal more effectively.
